TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . The respondent Government are represented by their Deputy Agent , Mr H .– PERSON , GPE , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant ’s late father was the owner of real estate located in GPE in GPE . In DATE the NORP PERSON seized that plot of land for the purpose of railway construction , but did not expropriate the land . In DATE the NORP ORG intended to buy that plot of land , but the negotiations between the applicant ’s father and the company failed . Following the foundation of GPE ( “ GPE ” ) on DATE ORG ( ORG ) of the GPE continued to use the land . The plot has a size of QUANTITY . At an unknown point of time the applicant ’s father left GPE .

At the time of the NORP reunification on DATE the applicant ’s father was listed as the real estate ’s owner in the land register ( Grundbuch ) . In DATE the NORP ORG and the applicant ’s father again negotiated the purchase of the land and agreed on a purchase price of CARDINAL MONEY ( ORG ) ( CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) . However , ORG of the former GPE withdrew its offer shortly before the signing of the contract .

Subsequently the NORP ORG of the former GPE and ORG of GPE ( ORG Bundesbahn ) merged to form ORG ( ORG ) , which is a ORG - owned company . ORG continues to use the plot of land in question . The applicant ’s father passed away on DATE and the applicant inherited the plot of land . A copy of the land register ( PERSON ) dated DATE lists the applicant as the current owner .
The applicant does not pay property tax ( ORG ) , but ORG does .

The applicant brought an action for delivery of possession ( Klage auf Herausgabe- rei vindicatio ) against ORG in ORG . On DATE ORG ordered ORG to deliver ( herausgeben ) the real estate . The court held that the applicant ’s father had never been expropriated and that the applicant was thus the owner . Furthermore , it found that the applicant ’s claim had not lapsed ( ist nicht erloschen ) according to LAW for ORG Caused by the War and the ORG of the NORP Reich ” ( “ PERSON allgemeinen GPE durch den FAC entstandener GPE – Allgemeines Kriegsfolgengesetz – hereinafter called the “ ORG ” – see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) . According to section CARDINAL of that act all claims against ORG or ORG are excluded , but according to ORG section CARDINAL claims of delivery of possession ( Herausgabeansprüche ) are to be satisfied by the successor of ORG and ORG .

However , according to LAW of DATE ( Einigungsvertrag ) only sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL , and not section DATE , of the aforementioned act were to apply in the territory of the former GPE ( neue ORG - hereinafter called new Länder ) . Nevertheless , ORG held that the aforementioned provisions had to be interpreted in conformity with LAW ) , and accordingly , the applicant ’s claim could not be excluded .

ORG confirmed the lower court ’s decision . It held that the applicant was the owner and that ORG possessed the real estate within the meaning of ORG . The court considered that the pertinent provisions of LAW could not be interpreted in accordance with LAW . However , it found that sections DATE and following of ORG had to be applied by analogy . It pointed out that when deciding on LAW the German ORG had been of the opinion that section DATE was no longer needed as no such claims existed anymore . Therefore , the ORG had overlooked that there was still a need for regulation of cases such as the present one . Hence sections DATE and following had to be applied by analogy , as there was no objective reason for treating the applicant ’s case differently from CARDINAL in which the real estate in question was located on the territory of GPE ( “ FRG ” ) prior to the NORP reunification ( alte Bundesländer- hereinafter called old ORG ) . The court also pointed out that the applicant was not entitled to any compensation under current NORP PERSON for her loss of possession , as the regulations which awarded compensation for acts of ORG required an act of expropriation .

While the proceedings were pending before the court , ORG offered the applicant to buy the real estate for ORG ( PERCENT ) per square metre , resulting in a purchase price of CARDINAL ORG . The applicant refused that offer .

ORG set aside the judgment of ORG . It acknowledged that the applicant was the property ’s owner ( ” die Klägerin ist Eigentümerin eines ... Grundstücks ” ) , but rejected her claim for delivery of possession .

The court found that section CARDINAL of ORG could not be applied by analogy as this would be contrary to the legislator ’s will . From the pertinent provisions of LAW it deduced that the legislator actually intended to treat the owners of real estate located in the old or new LOC differently . It found that , according to the travaux préparatoires , those provisions of LAW were meant to be a final settlement of the question of the damages caused by the war and the collapse of ORG . The court concluded that the legislator had not wished to include claims such as in the present case , because it considered that there was no further need for regulation . Furthermore , the court found that there was no indication that the legislator might have erroneously overlooked that in some particular cases the need for regulation persisted . On the contrary , the legislator had accepted that in some cases the aim of ORG could not be achieved .

The court held that the rejection of the applicant ’s action for delivery of possession did not violate the German Basic PERSON for the following reasons . The exclusion of claims for delivery of possession did not fall within the ambit of LAW , which guarantees the right to property ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) . It doubted that the applicant still had a right protected by that provision . The real estate had been in possession ( i QUANTITY Besitz ) of the GPE for DATE . Therefore , it found that the applicant ’s property had become an “ empty shell ” ( bloβe ORG ) . In any event , LAW was not applicable as LAW of LAW Basic PERSON was lex specialis in the present case ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) . It stipulates that the ORG can determine which liabilities of the GPE are to be satisfied .

The court pointed out that in the context of the NORP reunification similar questions had arisen as after DATE Second World War . In DATE ORG had passed the afore - mentioned ORG in order to determine the liabilities accumulated by ORG . To rectify the de facto bankruptcy of ORG , the ORG was in general allowed to repudiate the liabilities of ORG .

ORG held that this reasoning could be applied to the situation subsequent to the NORP reunification , as far as it concerned the damages caused by the war and the collapse of ORG with which the GPE had not dealt . Therefore , the ORG was entitled to choose which liabilities it would fulfil . The court stressed that the legislator , when assessing the ORG ’s financial capacity in this respect , enjoyed a wide margin of appreciation .

The court furthermore held that the applicant had not been discriminated against contrary to LAW see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) . It pointed out that under GPE law the applicant ’s right of ownership had already been diminished , as her real estate had been in public use during the entire time . Furthermore , there had been DATE between the end of the war and the NORP reunification . It concluded that the NORP legislator had had a wide margin of appreciation in this respect , in particular regarding the financing of the NORP reunification .

Lastly it found that even the fact that the applicant permanently lost the possession of her property while remaining proprietor did not make a difference . The court held that this had to be accepted ( hinnehmen ) by the applicant . It further denied any compensation under civil law for the continued use of the property by ORG , stating that such claims had lapsed as well according to ORG .
On DATE the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint solely invoking LAW ( prohibition of discrimination ) .

On DATE ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s complaint against the judgment of ORG and the above - mentioned provisions of LAW . It acknowledged that the applicant had suffered a disadvantage in comparison to owners whose property , located in the old Länder , had been seized by ORG during the war . However , the court found that this disadvantage did not breach LAW , as there were objective reasons for it . It found that the Second World War had led to the establishment of GPE with different forms of Government and social orders . Each ORG had dealt with the damages caused by the war and the collapse of ORG in a different way and was responsible for those caused in its territory . Therefore , the ORG was under no obligation to compensate for damages which had not been taken care of by the GPE . Moreover , the court found that the ORG would have been administratively and financially overstrained with that task in any event . It concluded that the disadvantage suffered by the applicant was reasonable ( zumutbar ) , in particular because , DATE after DATE , the applicant could not expect to ever resume possession of her property again .
